block.p: Army's Role Questioned In Colombian Massacre The Colombian government says it has been working hard to sever the remnants of ties between the armed forces and paramilitaries. But human rights groups, pointing to incidents like a February 1999 massacre in El Salado, say that links remain and that mechanisms to monitor and punish commanders and units have had limited success.

Private Meeting at Camp David Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, held an impromptu meeting at Mr. Arafat's cabin at Camp David, unaccompanied by any American negotiator. The substance of what was said was not described in the State Department's brief account.

Vietnam and U.S. Sign Accord The United States and Vietnam signed a trade agreement that, if implemented fully, would transform America's onetime enemy from a quasi-socialist redoubt into Asia's newest capitalist recruit.

Strained Smiles in China Defense Secretary William S. Cohen and Chinese leaders ended two days of high-level meetings in Beijing with hopeful pledges of cooperation and friendship, despite evidence of deep rifts over important military policies and Chinese suspicions about American intentions in Asia.
Disclosures in Mexican Scandal Opposition lawmakers disclosed the names of about 3,300 wealthy debtors linked to questionable bank loans that became part of a huge government bailout.
Hostages Freed in Fiji The leader of a coup in Fiji freed the ousted prime minister and 17 others, ending a hostage standoff.

Missile Measure Rejected The Senate narrowly rejected an effort to require more stringent and thorough testing of a proposed national missile defense system, five days after the failure of a crucial missile test.

Lawmakers Seek to Ban Most Gambling on Internet A tentative deal has been reached in the House of Representatives on a bitterly fought bill to ban most forms of gambling on the Internet, clearing the way for a floor vote as early as next week.

Senate Upholds Gas Tax The Senate voted overwhelmingly against suspending the federal gasoline tax through the November election, calling the measure an effort to cozy up to voters at the expense of the nation's roads and highways.

Bradley Endorses Gore Bill Bradley emerged from months of political seclusion to endorse Vice President Al Gore, his former primary foe, and to help Mr. Gore appeal to independent voters in the presidential race.
Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, who had long been seen in his family as the one with the greatest political promise, has been crowded off the national stage by his older brother.
Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Gore exchanged sharp comments over a $610 million shortfall in the Texas state budget.

Philadelphia on the Defense Philadelphia suffered the ignominy of seeing its police on national television beating and kicking a man accused of stealing a police car and shooting at an officer. Police Commissioner John F. Timoney, above, dismissed any comparison to the videotaped 1991 clubbing of Rodney J. King.

Congress and D.C. at Odds House Republicans are angry about a proposed District of Columbia ordinance requiring insurance companies to cover prescription contraceptives routinely and plan to try to overturn it.

House Backs Abortion Limits The House of Representatives narrowly voted to maintain restrictions on the ability of private organizations that receive federal funds to use their own money to provide abortions overseas.

Expansive Ambitions Dig Deep Hole for a Health Plan Many of Anthony L. Watson's ambitions for the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York have failed, burying HIP in a deep financial hole. Expanding into other states has led to big losses, and regulators are investigating whether he squandered millions of dollars on lavish salaries and executive perquisites.
Collapse at a Salvage Shop A wall and two floors collapsed at an architectural salvage shop in the East Village, forcing the evacuation of 51 apartments in three nearby buildings.

Aged Cheeses Under Scrutiny The federal Food and Drug Administration says a growing body of literature suggests that aged cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, the bedrock of many premier cheeses, could pose a health hazard.
School Construction Approved The New Jersey Assembly gave final approval to the largest school construction program in state history, a $12 billion plan.
Human Hand in Global Warming A new analysis of the climate of the last 1,000 years suggests that human activity is the dominant force behind the sharp global warming trend.
AIDS Therapy as Babies' Shield A simple drug regimen may help protect babies from infection by the AIDS virus, a study found.

Risks to the East Coast Research suggests that the East Coast is far more geologically active than had been thought and that the outer sloping edge of the continental shelf has the potential to cave in.

General Mills May Buy Pillsbury General Mills said it was in talks to acquire Diageo's Pillsbury division. Analysts said the deal could be completed by early next week at a price of $9 billion to $11 billion.

Phone Merger Called Off WorldCom and Sprint officially abandoned their $115 billion merger, bowing to pressure from regulators concerned that the creation of such a large telecommunications company would stifle competition.

Nasdaq Continues Rally Strong quarterly reports from several companies touched off fresh buying in technology stocks, lifting the Nasdaq composite index to a second consecutive solid gain as the rest of the market mostly languished.

Big Book Fee for G.E. Chairman Time Warner Trade Publishing acquired the right to publish a book by John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of General Electric, for a record advance of $7.1 million, more than advances paid for books by Gen. Colin L. Powell and the pope.
